title: 111_hr3694
content: The Act may be cited as the "Removing Excess Litigation Involving Energy on Federal Lands Act" or the "RELIEF Act". Congress finds that the United States spends over $1 billion per day importing crude oil, which is the largest wealth transfer in history. The US has significant oil and natural gas reserves in the outer Continental Shelf, but legal challenges by environmental groups delay energy resources reaching the public, causing high costs to the economy. Expedited judicial review is deemed necessary to prevent abuse of the judicial system. Exclusive jurisdiction over causes and claims related to covered energy projects is granted to the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. All causes and claims must be filed within 60 days of the action or decision by a Federal official, or they will be barred. All causes and claims related to covered energy projects must be filed within 60 days of the action or decision by a Federal official. Proceedings must be resolved within 180 days of filing and take precedence over other matters. Failure to comply with the deadline results in dismissal with prejudice. Appellate review can only be sought from the Supreme Court. SEC. 6. Ability to seek appellate review from the Supreme Court for interlocutory or final judgments, decrees, or orders of the district court. SEC. 7. Deadline for appeal to the Supreme Court within 180 days of the district court's decision. SEC. 8. Limitation on the scope of review and relief. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON SCOPE OF REVIEW AND RELIEF. In judicial review of Federal actions, administrative findings are presumed correct unless proven otherwise. Prospective relief must be narrowly drawn and minimally intrusive to correct violations. SEC. 9. LEGAL FEES. SEC. 9. LEGAL FEES. Any person filing a petition for judicial review under this Act must pay prevailing parties' fees unless the Court finds their position justified. SEC. 10. EXCLUSION. This Act does not apply to disputes between lease parties. SEC. 11. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. SEC. 10. EXCLUSION. This Act does not apply to disputes between lease parties. SEC. 11. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. It refers to actions by Federal officials regarding leasing Federal lands for energy exploration and production.
